product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Two steps forward, two steps back
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 28, 2022
text: The Switch OLED screen is a little bigger, and the bright colors pop. But parts of the screen have a green tint that's more pronounced at certain brightness levels, and darker grey-ish colors have a static fuzzy overlay at any brightness level. Seems like Nintendo sourced some leftover OLED screens with no QC for these and it shows, definitely not worth upgrading.They also covered the screen in a thin layer of plastic that scratches really easily. I understand why -- the Switch OLED is supposed to be kid friendly, and the plastic is supposed to keep any shattered glass contained if you drop it. But I don't take mine any further than the couch, and it already has a couple small but annoying scratches after less than two months, whereas my V2 didn't have any after two years.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: No warranty from Nintendo and avoid OLED.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 22, 2022
text: The C input in the console quit working after 9 months. Amazon replaces within a year if you buy within a Window for Christmas but of course it‚Äôs sold out so I bought it in January. After an hour long chat I got the Nintendo warranty fine print.  If they determine it‚Äôs your fault you pay. If they can‚Äôt repair it they will send you an old one with scratches, etc. Asurion warranty was much better in that it provides for accidents. This was clearly a defect but Nintendo won‚Äôt own it. It‚Äôs a shame. My whole family has Switches and I have the only OLED. It‚Äôs newest but first to fail. I‚Äôm granny so not even hard on it compared to the kids with theirs.

When it is not crashing the battery drains from full charge to one percent in minutes, so now I'm stuck with a $350 dollar paper weight.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Looking For Fun? Look No Further
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2023
text: The Nintendo Switch, in particular the OLED model, is arguably the best Nintendo system to date. With the ability to play NES, SNES, N64, GB & GBA via its subscription service along with a variety of first party titles (Mario Kart, Super Smash Bros, Zelda), there‚Äôs really no way to pick one up and not find something to do. Is it as powerful as a PS5 or an XBOX Series X? Nope. Where as they play games at a steady 60 frames per second, the switch plays games at half the rate at 30 frames. This detail may me little to you as since it‚Äôs not particularly easy to tell, especially on first party games. But when it comes to ports of big games like Skyrim or The Witcher 3, it runs them as well as it can but they‚Äôre significantly more fun on systems that can handle their hardware. It‚Äôs impressive that a portable system can play them at the cost of performance, though.If you‚Äôre looking for a video game console that you can play on the go and at home and you‚Äôre not focused on playing games at 60 FPS, the Switch OLED is without a doubt a great option. Its versatility, accessibility, and overall quality will help you make memories for years to come.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Great Product
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2022
text: I find the Nintendo Switch a great product to buy.  Some reasons that drew me into buying such an expensive gaming console is because the Switch is portable, has lots of interesting games, and has a lot of cool features.First, the Nintendo swich is portable.  It is almost considered a handheld device.  I can play with the Switch on the couch, hook it up to my computer or television.  The possibilities are endless.  When I go on a trip, I can pack it up and take it with me.  I can‚Äôt really do that with the Xbox or the Playstation.  The Xbox and the Playstation have to be connected to the TV in order to play with it, not to mention all of the wires and plugs that have to be packed up.  It‚Äôs not convenient like the Nintendo Switch.  The new Switch has a battery life of 9 hours compared to the older models which was 6.5 hours. That‚Äôs almost 3 more hours per charge.  The screen is approximately 6.2 inches which is comfortable for my eyes so that they don't have to squint to look at the screen.  The detachable joy cons are really nice to have.  They are light and wrap around your wrist.  The switch is not like any gaming console out there.  It‚Äôs a one of a kind because it‚Äôs a gaming console that is portable and that can also hook up to your TV.  There is nothing else out there like it.Next, the Switch offers a wide variety of games from fighting games like Super Smash bros, racing games like Mario Kart, to building simulators like Minecraft.  They also have developed a wide variety of fantasy games like the Legend of Zelda.  My favorite game to play with my family is Mario Kart because it has different characters, challenges, race courses and cars to choose from. It‚Äôs very interactive so you feel like you are actually in the game yourself.  I can play it for hours because it is so addicting.Lastly,  the overall look of the Switch is just awesome.  The design is simple but comes in a variety of colors and themes.  You can buy different color joycons (controller) and a pro controller along with  different color cases to make the Switch your very own.  The choices are endless and are what caught my eyes.Overall at $299, I think the Nintendo Switch is a good buy.  It‚Äôs very portable, has a wide variety of games for the family and has a very sleek design.  I would recommend buying one if it is within your budget and you love to play games.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: 51 year old Gamer Dad weighs in ‚ÄúDo not Fault the Switch because of Scalpers‚Äù Best Switch period.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2021
text: Thoughts of a 51 year old gamer dad.I wish people would stop faulting the system because of People‚Äôs Greed. The Switch isn‚Äôt at fault - it‚Äôs scalpers and resellers that use bots to buy up all the stock in a heartbeat and then resell at 2-5 times MSRP. The problem with the current Pre-Order system is merchants like Wally, Amazonian, Besties Buy, and others allow this practice to continue to happen. Your anger needs to be directed at them for not doing something to prevent this. Limiting sales of 1 per house hold, Address, or verified IP address would limit this but all these retailers seem either too dumb or just don‚Äôt care to enact it because they are selling their stock. This same issue has happened with PS5s and the newer Xbox‚Äôs too. However Tar-ja√© üéØ does limit their sales. Which is how I was able to get a system for my son and myself. One of each color. Anyway I didn‚Äôt want this to be the review of the purchase - because I understand peoples frustration, just they are taking their anger out on the product instead of the real reason that is upsetting them.As to the Switch OLED, it is by far the superior system. There is a premium feel to this new unit compared to the older version. For and extra $50 you are getting double memory space out of the box, a true glass OLED screen which makes your whole library of Switch games come back alive. There is no comparison‚Ä¶.the OLED screen is stunningly beautiful. You can really tell on any game that has black on screen. Luigi‚Äôs Mansion, Metroid Dread, and any underground Mario level, and Breath of the Wild will simply take your breath away‚Ä¶again. Then the build quality is just incredible. The bezel on the front (what there is of it) is metal, the body length kick stand and side rails are all metal. So, Joy Cons not only lock into place but feel incredibly sturdy this time around. No Hamburglar ‚Äúwobble wobble‚Äù - if you get that joke you‚Äôre my people.  A newer designed dock with has 4K upscaling built in? And the included HDMI cable is also 4K compatible this time around‚Ä¶.those all inflate the cost of production so I can‚Äôt see that being a coincidence. Nintendo has plans to use those upgrades.  So all the complaints I‚Äôve heard about the $50 price bump seem nonsensical. I‚Äôd honestly say it‚Äôs worth more then $350 but Nintendo did what it did to keep it at that price point - including scaling down the packaging this time around to save on cost where they could‚Ä¶.which I would rather have more system and less cardboard.So when you can, and find these in the wild or back on retail shelves - Don‚Äôt line a scalpers pocket - you should definitely upgrade your system if you‚Äôre a Nintendo fan. I personally love the system and my son loves his. They were well worth the retail price.

title: Definitely a better quality
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 13, 2022
text: Instead of buying the console when it first came out I decided to wait for it to go back to the original price because I didn‚Äôt need to buy it right away. I had the first switch that came out until I gave it to my nephew because he was constantly wanting to play it and He ended up breaking it so I was like, here yah go kid‚Ä¶ you get to keep my $300 console lmao. It was well worth the wait though! I‚Äôm liking the redesign, and I‚Äôm privy to both handheld and TV game play. It‚Äôs always best going into something  without having high expectations that people seem to have a lot these days of. That‚Äôs how disappointment is created imo. Honestly, I‚Äôve got way more in my possession now than I ever thought with my old switch. I‚Äôm extremely pleased with the slight upgrade, the screen the size of the screen and the display is beautiful, it‚Äôs what I had expected with it being an OLED given my experience with OLED (a realistic expectation of course). I definitely give it 5 stars and will cherish this for years to come! If you‚Äôre looking for a better upgrade, you‚Äôre not going to find a console like this for $50 more than the original that came out before it. Buy it.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: A worthy upgrade for me
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 11, 2022
text: I have the original version 1. Then I also bought the Lite when it came out, but after a while I just felt like the screen was too small. I went back to my version 1 and was getting tired of picking it up to play it and finding the battery always needed charging. So I took a chance on this OLED and I'm finding the battery life is pretty much doubled. Other improvements:PROS:Much longer battery life via better power managementGlass screenBigger screen size/smaller bezelsColors look much more vivid and sharp, games look better than everMuch improved audio speakersMore memory (only 64GB, but still double the previous versions)Better kick standImproved dock, can now use a wired Internet connectionTighter Joycon connections to the consoleImproved WiFi receptionCONS:Same processorYou might also need new accessories to fit the slightly larger sizeOnly 4K on TV screenFramerate? Example: while Metroid Dread looks fantastic and is supposedly 60fps while playing, the framerate drops to 30fps in the faster cut scenes. It's pretty noticeable.OVERALL:The $350 price is steep for lacking 4K in handheld mode, no processor upgrade, minimal memory upgrade and the same framerate as previous versions, but there are the improvements to consider. Seems like another Nintendo wallet-grab release, but not a total teaser. In the end I'm very happy with the device. It's hard to recommend upgrading to the OLED from the previous V2 Switch, but as an upgrade from the V1 or the Lite, you might want to consider it after you factor in additional things like tax, shipping, extended warrantee, re-purchasing any accessories that don't accommodate the OLED's slightly lager size, and new screen protectors, before you decide if it's worth the final total to upgrade.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Switch 2.0? Yes & No
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2021
text: Hard to believe 4 years ago, Nintendo really came back from the brink of despair with the release of the Nintendo Switch. The console took the concepts from the Wii & Wii U and made it the mainstream for gamers to enjoy their favorite video games at home & on-the-go. The hybrid console is definitely a game changer in fun. There also have been so many wonderful titles that also came around the bend with the Switch like The Legend Of Zelda: Breath Of The Wild, Super Mario Odyssey and Animal Crossing: New Horizons. The Switch also spawned other versions of the console like the handheld Switch Lite, which brought handheld gamers into the console line, with some bells & whistles a few years ago, with strong results. Now, Nintendo is taking the basic Switch hybrid and expanding it for handheld gamers young and old, with better results.The Nintendo Switch OLED brings in all the strong concepts of the original Switch and expanding it with a brighter OLED screen. The hybrid console may not be as unique as the original Switch, but takes it a step up for those that might not want to play the console outside of connecting it to the TV, with a brighter screen, a stronger battery life and a bigger memory and storage for your favorite Switch games like Yoshi's Crafted World and recent titles like Metroid Dread and Super Monkey Ball Banana Mania. Looking at the console and playing underrated games like Sonic Forces and Pac-Man 99 was a absolute joy and incredibly fun to behold on the hold and looked better than when hey were originally released.I found it to be a joy playing the Switch more in handheld mode here in this console, the screen looked much better and brighter, like it does on my TV. It feels good. You also have a few extra improvements here too such as a built-in stand so you can use it more in the underwhelming tabletop mode from before, which is a better joy while playing gems that you could not play in handheld mode like 1,2, Switch and Super Mario Party. It felt pristine and clean. The new and improved joy-cons work just as well as the original ones Nintendo made and feels neat and clean. I found them to be better for control and just easier to manage than the original ones. The new dock also steps up nicely, with a few flukes though. For myself, it might not be as tight as the original Switch dock, it feels a little looser, but when connected to the internet with ethernet, you get a stronger internet connection for downloading games, or streaming games with Switch Online. There are just a lot of improvements that take the original Switch and uniquely makes it a little better in the end that makes the games feel better than ever.But nevertheless, the Switch OLED has a few faults within it, and than is largely going to depend on the kind of Switch gamer you happen to be. For one, not all of the accessories are compatible to the Switch OLED. That shows with accessories and grips from third-party companies. So, you may need to upgrade in the end for some cases and peripherals. Also, if you are primarily playing the Switch in handheld mode only, you might not want to upgrade to the newer console, because it does not offer anything new to grab you and just stick with the Switch Lite. Also, it does not have a faster processor than the original Switch does, considered it was planned for the Switch Pro model, which intentionally was going to be planned with the OLED model and sadly because of the processor shortage that has effected tech companies world, you have the 2019 processor that was included with the remodeled 2019 version. Not that it is a bad thing to worry about, but for those that did get the 2019 revised original Switch model, you might not want to buy the Switch OLED model.When it does come down to the Switch OLED, it handles well in the very end and you mainly get what you paid for. Truthfully, the Switch OLED is not a model for everybody in the end, and that can be a the one blow with the system. If you have the 2017 model, and need to the upgrade to the Switch OLED because of a better battery life of extra memory for games, that would be a yes. If you own a Switch Lite and never had the fullest Switch experience with the original hybrid, that would also be a yes. However, if you bought the 2019 revised Switch model, you might want to go into the Switch OLED, because all you would be getting would be the better screen and you may want to wait for a newer more improved model of the Switch down the road. But with my experience with the Nintendo Switch OLED, I'm having a lot of fun with it, and playing more in handheld than what I had played the original Switch. I do recommend you play around with the Switch OLED and kick back and have a lot of fun with the next step up in the Switch hybrid legacy.Graphics: A-Sound: AControl: A-Fun & Enjoyment: B+ for solo play; B+ for multiplayerOverall: B+

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Faulty Joy-Con and disappointing service from Nintendo
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2022
text: After only 2 weeks of owning this and very minimal use, especially to the button that isn't working, the down button on the D-pad for the switch requires 8x more force to activate than the rest of them, I put it on my scale and all the other buttons register when the scale reads around 100g, but the down button doesn't register until I press hard enough for the scale to read 800-1000g, which is just not acceptable for playing. So I got a faulty Joy-Con, not that big of a deal, but Nintendo's solution to the problem was to ask me to send my Joy-Con in for repair, so after only 2 weeks of owning it I'm going to have to wait another 2 weeks (not sure how long repair takes, just guessing) without being able to play it? This doesn't seem like a fair way to handle faulty products to me, so I'm giving this 1 star, I like the system, but it clearly can come with flaws, and then the service to resolve them is just so disappointing. So just be aware when buying this that if something goes wrong, you're not going to have a good time.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2021
text: We have an old Switch we got years ago that the kids have used heavily.  We thought it would be nice to get the Switch Oled since they both love to play so many single player games. I've de-registered the old nintendo as their Primary Switch, but now they can't play any of the games on the old switch.  They are going to be upset that they can't play anything till christmas.If I'm forking out $60 dollars a game for my kids, Nintendo shouldn't be telling me they can't play. This feels like overstepping.  If this isn't resolvable I'm done with them.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Nintendo Oled Switch from Amazon Treasure Truck
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2021
text: First, this is my second Nintendo Switch system.  My first is the Mario edition switch and it still functions well.  Despite only small incremental upgrades with the Oled version, here are my main reasons for the upgrade:1.  My eyes are getting old, so at a slightly larger clearer oled display, it helps with the visual in handheld mode.  With the original, I noticed that I tend to leave it docked and hardly used it as a handheld.2. Lots of reviews fail to mention that I can finally link my wireless bluetooth headphone.  That was sorely missing from my Mario edition Switch.  Headphones vastly improve handheld functioning and enjoyment.Nintendo Oled is not a next gen console, and I get that.  It just come with enough improvements for me to justify upgrading.  I am looking forward to going back into my library of games and replaying some of the old games I have, in handheld mode.  At $350 MSRP (please try not to purchase scalping prices), I recommend it as a buy.  I dare say safe and spend the extra cash on the oled version versus the switch lite edition. Good luck and happy holidays.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Love it!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2021
text: I have never owned a Nintendo Switch before this purchase, so the experience was completely new to me. I was very surprised that the controller with the screen actually IS the console. You just sit the console into a charger and it becomes a TV console. Mind blown. The box was surprisingly small, I guess because the console is so tiny. Very easy to set up and get running, although the annoying part was linking Nintendo accounts (theres two different types) from my 3DS XL and phone apps, and getting everything connected. Once done though, its super simple. Pleasantly surprised by the games available in the eshop. Lots of indie games and good games on sale for $1.99 and $4.99. Its a lot of the same indie games I see on Steam (PC), and I wasn't expecting that. No complaints so far. Will update if I experience the dreaded joycon drift or any other issue.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: If you have a lite or the first generation switch this is worth the upgrade
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2022
text: I am absolutely in love with the OLED. I had the original first generation switch and I liked it but the battery life and the sound volume was lacking to say the least. This upgrade is Amazing. I get easily 3 extra hours on it compared to the original switch and I no longer have to wear headphones to hear my game. Also that extra inch in the screen makes a huge difference. You would think it wouldn‚Äôt because it‚Äôs only an inch but it really does. Not having that black border around the screen is very nice and slick and the extra enteral storage is great!!! My younger brother had the second version of the switch that has a better battery and when you compare his to the OLED there‚Äôs not that big of a difference when it comes to the battery so unless you just absolutely want the bigger slicker screen it may not be worth the upgrade but if you do have the original like me it‚Äôs more than worth it.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Not worth buying if you already have a switch- otherwise, it's the one to get!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2021
text: In short- it's a great console, but I wouldn't recommend it if you already have one and usually keep it docked. If you primarily use handheld mode or own a Lite, it might be worth the upgrade for you. If you're a first-time buyer, this is the one to get.Most of the hardware is identical to the previous revision, so I'll go over what matters:DESIGN: In addition to an overall much more modernized design, the whole device has a much better quality to it and feels sturdy in the hands. It's a much more premium console, both in look and feel.SCREEN: It's larger, brighter, and more vibrant. Putting it next to an original switch makes the old screen look dull and dated. The glass screen is covered in a layer of plastic, so make sure to pick up a screen protector.KICKSTAND: It feels sturdy and easily moves to whatever position you'd like. I've actually used it quite a lot more then I expected to. It's a great upgrade from the flimsy kickstand on the original switch.DOCK: It looks nicer and has an ethernet port. Not much else to it.OTHER: The internal storage is doubled to 64gb, which is always nice to see. The speakers also sound a bit better compared to the original console.In short- for people who prefer handheld mode, it's pretty nice. If you can justify buying it, the quality of life improvements are great.

text: I'm so glad I managed to get this at $350. It's definitely worth upgrading over the old Switch model if you play handheld. If you're buying a Switch and plan on playing handheld, get this. If you play 100% on the TV then it's not really worth it, but the screen is a lot nicer to play handheld.At first when I got it, I didn't notice a big difference in the screen, but then I started playing games and it was a huge difference. The speakers are also much higher quality. If you play handheld, are thinking of upgrading and can afford it or sell off / give away your old Switch, do it. If it's a new Switch purchase, just get the OLED if you can find it at $350 (just have to keep checking until there is a restock).

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Awesome system.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 7, 2022
options: Color: Neon Blue and Red | Style: Console
text: Versatility defines this system and it rocks.  It doesn't boast the power of the bigger PS* or XBox* systems but the graphics are really good and the game writers are obviously pushing the available hardware to it's limits.  Games such as Zelda Breath of the Wild have scenes that cause the rendering hardware to stagger because they are so rich.  It's not a problem but rather a testament to the quality they are trying to offer.The magic of this system is being able to play the newer versions of games that you grew up with.  Seeing Zelda come to life after playing on 16-bit hardware is like watching Michael Bay bring the Transformers to life.  Truly amazing.The system can be used on a TV or as a portable handheld console and has a built-in stand for a table top mode.  You can play multiplayer both on a single system on the TV or by networking multiple consoles either over a local network or the internet for Play with remote friends.The game selection available is amazing.  There's not only new versions of your favorites but you can play the classics as well with a subscription that has a family pass option.The newer OLED model is definitely worth the extra few dollars if your on the fence.  We bought 2, one for each boy, and the only problem we're having is that you can only play games on a single console at a time unless you buy a 2nd chip.  This is mostly just an issue for single player games like Zelda when they become household favorites and everyone wants a turn.  Having effective parental controls provides a solution for that problem though.

The amazing screen on it is a great step up from the old. I was watching the old one that my friend plays and seeing the difference was incredible. It‚Äôs a huge step up as it‚Äôs way more vibrant and immersive, the sharp colours, and the amazing back stand give it a different feel than the old one. I‚Äôm so glad I waited to get the new OLED rather that get the first generation. Incredible running and amazing for handheld mode as well as when it‚Äôs docked. It‚Äôs great for travel and I use it all the time 10/10 would buy again.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Awesome Platform
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 18, 2023
options: Color: Neon Blue and Red | Style: Console
text: Awesome product.The Switch platform is a great solution for on the go life. I like that it is small enough to not take up too much real estate in my entertainment center.  The included dock for the joysticks is nice as it feels like a regular controller.  The buttons are a bit smaller than I'm used to and the button mapping is pretty opposite from Playstation which has been a small learning curve for me since I have not played a Nintendo system since the N64. The user menu is something new for me as well.The load speeds seem pretty fast however when using the Nintendo store the browser seems a slow. I really like that whatever game you were playing is readily available on the menu and you can go between game and menu quickly and easily.I don't believe Netflix can be viewed on the Switch but other services I think are available.I feel like the console should come with a screen protector as the original model's screen would scratch from the dock, so if you do not have one, be careful when re-docking.

title: Love the switch for family game nights and solo play.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 3, 2023
text: I recently purchased the Nintendo Switch OLED model as a gift for my fiancee, and she has been thrilled with it. The OLED display is a significant improvement over the standard model, providing brighter, more vibrant colors and deeper blacks. The handheld mode is also a nice touch, allowing her to take the Switch with her on the go.In terms of gaming performance, the Switch has exceeded our expectations. The games run smoothly and look great on the OLED display. The included Joy-Con controllers are comfortable to hold and provide a good level of precision.The build quality of the Switch is also top-notch. It feels solid and well-constructed, and we have no concerns about it breaking or malfunctioning. The included dock is also a nice touch, allowing us to easily switch between handheld and TV modes.Overall, we are extremely satisfied with our purchase of the Nintendo Switch OLED model. It provides excellent gaming performance, portability, and value for the price. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a new gaming console.

text: Nintendo do has a history of making special edition consoles and sometimes I want them but a fair amount I can pass on.This splatoon system pushed me over the edge it was so cool and would be a perfect replacement for my launch switchI am worried about joycon drift so I will use my original bad joycons but the design brings me great joy.The system itself is beautiful,coming from someone who used their switch religiously this is a nice upgrade.6.2 to 7 inches, the stand is a million times easier to open and way more functional than before,and not to mention 64gb of internal storage.I can't rave as much about the removal of a USB port for the ethernet and I don't use the dock at all since this would be identical to my original switchOverall I would say that the switch oled is a fantastic replacement for anyone rocking an older potentially worse for wear system or someone who doesn't have a switch already.For me I support nintendo and want to continue to see great things so I speak with my wallet

title: Excellent screen. Works as advertised. Well worth price.

text: Excellent screen. Works as advertised. Doesn't seem like it, but it is well worth the $350 price tag. It is the premium version of then Nintendo Switch Lite. If you are primarily using in TV hook-up mode you won't get your money's worth stick with original switch. If you are using mostly in portable or semi-portable mode (ie using the unit's screen) it is well worth the money. The switch lite still has its place -- for the kids you don't entirely trust to be reasonably gentle with it, or not get it unit and/or account banned using hacked firmware for pirate ROMs. The cases for OLED switch aren't that great. The switch light can get tougher cases because no need to accommodate detachable joycons.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Love it
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2022
text: I definitely recommend third party joycons or a big grip case. This replaced my Lite that started drifting, the stock joycons are so uncomfortable, even compared to the lite without a grip case. I bought a case with just the little humps on the back like my lite grip case, but that didn't work well and got controller shaped joycons for $40 and couldn't be happier, the ones I got charge on and with the switch but also have individual batteries, they have LEDs around the sticks but I leave them off to save battery life. The system itself is exactly the same, the big screen helps my aging millennial eyes not need to squint. It's got more vibrant colors viola an option in the menu that comes automatically on, which imo makes some games look oversaturated, but most games looks great with it. The battery life is amazing compared to the Lite, feels almost double. As far as I know literally everything else is the same inside the console, games all run the same, the resolution is the same. So far in 3 months I've only played handheld which is the biggest downfall of the system, it's uncomfortable out of the box, it is 100% necessary to buy a grip case or controller shaped joycons.

product_name: Nintendo Switch ‚Äì OLED Model w/ Neon Red & Neon Blue Joy-Con
title: Probably one of my favorite ‚Äúconsole‚Äù purchases of the year
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 6, 2022
options: Color: Neon Blue and Red | Style: Console
text: Wow, wow, wow. Well let‚Äôs start by saying. I‚Äôm a handheld kinda girl, but I love traditional console gaming as well. This year alone I‚Äôve invested in the PS5, xbox series S, the steam deck and I still okay on my psvita that I‚Äôve had for a few years. And man does the Nintendo really really compete. So let‚Äôs compare the switch to each of these consolesNintendo vs Ps5: playstation clearly has a lager game collection way more variety etc. It‚Äôs a big beautiful console that takes up a lot of space. But the graphics are nice. Ive had it for about a month and I think it‚Äôs fine. Ive played spider man, stray, cyberpunk and some other games similar to those. (Open world) it‚Äôs good. Now on my switch the biggest pro is. I can take it literally anywhere without the need for wifi as long as I have the cartridges. It‚Äôs a beautiful oled screen that comes with it, a large section of games and I call this a jrpg powerhouse. I only play my jrpgs handheld. Psvita, even using psremote play to play the final fantasy series which is a hassle if your wifi isn‚Äôt the most stable on the planet lol. A lot of jrpg games are about $20 cheaper on the switch than it is the steam deck so that‚Äôs a plus.  I guess all in all it can‚Äôt really be compared to the ps5 but I can say I‚Äôve had my switch for a few days and have played on here more than I‚Äôve played on the ps5 so far.Switch oled vs psvita: I‚Äôm one of the people without the oled vita‚Äôs so right off the rip the oled switches screen is 100x better, brighter, and more beautiful. Before the switch I used to play all types of jrpgs on my vita. The old final fantasy series (very gritty and doesn‚Äôt look thag good especially compared to the remasters on ps4/ switch/ps5 and steam deck.) all of my games on my vita was free so that was a plus. (I won‚Äôt get into that here though)üòÇ now I love my vita. Probably my top 3 favorite‚Ä¶ consoles? But after playing the switch and compare the exact same games. The difference is night and day and I‚Äôm honestly really sad because it seems this may be my last year even picking up the vita as the switch is slowly taking over my attention.Also the screen is bigger so that‚Äôs a plus. Playing persona on the switch is way better than psvitaSwitch vs steam deck. Okay steam deck wins by a ballpark just due to the amount of games to choose for alone. I mean really, nearly your entire triple A steam library. BUT it‚Äôs so heavy, so bulky and I‚Äôm never ever taking out of the house just due to the price and how long I waited to get it. Plus it‚Äôs a handheld but portability isn‚Äôt really in the picture unless you take a huge bookbag with you everywhere you go lol. I love the steam deck. I play it all the time. The only things the switch has on the steam deck is portability, The oled screen, and the Nintendo library of course. You can‚Äôt play Zelda, Mario and nearly any Nintendo games on the deck. And as I stated above the JRPG games are cheaper on the switch than the deck. But steams notorious discounts can creep up on you and you can get a bunch of games for like $40 I love thag, Nintendo doesn‚Äôt have really many good discounts on games. And lastly for the deck. Man it gets loud as heck lol.Xbox about the same that I‚Äôd say for the ps5 but if my internet connection was more stable then cloud gaming probably would have beat the switch by a few points. This is just my personal experience. I like playing cloud gaming in the home (btw cloud gaming is a mobile xbox gamepass playing via internet connection on iOS devices, pc and android) so mobile video game service. The best out there and it‚Äôs only $15.00 a month. I like it for the home but for me the point of mobile gaming is being able to play anywhere. But public wifi at work, out shopping etc is not stable at all. So the switch wins in this category.For kids. By far I say the switch. Everytime I pick up the switch I wish I had a child of my own to share it with. If I had this when I was a kid, I would‚Äôve been the happiest kid ever.For adults I say it depends on what you like. If you like nostalgia then absolutely yes. If you like portability yes‚úÖ If you like playing cod, halo infinite, Miles morales, metro exodus etc. Console is way better for you. Even a steam deck by far.

title: Awesome-versatile
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 21, 2022
text: I love the versatility of it. I can play it on the go and easily tranfert it to my big tv. I can either play it solo or with someone else. It's my 1st time ever getting a nintendo after years. It's very relaxing to play. And for the versatility and the larger screen than earlier version, I think the price of this one is totally worth it. 100% recommend.

title: Poor remote battery life
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2022
text: Overall it's an OK machine.  Remote is small and uncomfortable, remotes battery life is terrible.  Don't expect games to appear as good on this as a PS5, they will not.

title: Fantastic
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2022
text: I had a very very old switch from when they first came out, the ones you can mod. I'm very very happy with the new, much longer battery life, and the beautiful OLED screen, I used to hate handheld play but now I love it. Playing breath of the wild has nearly blinded me several times with the bright and vivid colors
